questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • All the statements are true about Serous otitis media except option D.
  • Grommet insertion is done on the Anteroinferior quadrant of the tympanic membrane.

Serous Otitis Media:

  • This is an insidious condition characterised by the accumulation of non-purulent effusion in the middle ear cleft.
  • Often, the effusion is thick and viscid, but sometimes it may be thin and serous. The fluid is nearly sterile. The condition is commonly seen in school-going children. Option B ruled out.
  • This is the most common cause of conductive deafness in children less than 12 years old and is associated with adenoid hypertrophy. Option A ruled out.
  • In unilateral disease in an adult, Nasopharyngoscopy should be done as a priority to rule out Nasopharyngeal carcinoma. Option C ruled out.

Pathogenesis:

  • Malfunctioning of the eustachian tube.
  • Increased secretory activity of the middle ear.

Clinical features:

The disease affects children of 5-8 years of age. The symptoms include:

  • Hearing loss: This is the presenting and sometimes the only symptom. It is insidious in onset and rarely exceeds 40 dB. Deafness may pass unnoticed by the parents and may be accidentally discovered during audiometric screening tests.
  • Delayed and defective speech: Because of hearing loss, the development of speech is delayed or defective.
  • Mild earaches: There may be a history of upper respiratory tract infections with mild ear aches.

Otoscopic Findings:

  • The tympanic membrane is often dull and opaque with loss of light reflex. It may appear yellow, grey or bluish.
  • Thin leash of blood vessels may be seen along the handle of the malleus or at the periphery of the tympanic membrane and differs from marked congestion of acute suppurative otitis media.
  • Tympanic membranes may show varying degrees of retraction. Sometimes, it may appear full or slightly bulging in its posterior part due to effusion.
  • Fluid level and air bubbles may be seen when the fluid is thin and the tympanic membrane is transparent. Mobility of the tympanic membrane is restricted.

Treatment:

Medical:

  • Decongestants.
  • Anti-allergic drugs.
  • Antibiotics
  • Middle ear aeration(Vulsalva).

Surgical:

  • Myringotomy and aspiration of the fluid.
  • Grommet insertion.
  • Tympanotomy or cortical mastoidectomy.
  • Surgical treatment of the causative factor.

questions.text: A 52-year-old patient presenting with right-sided hearing loss has been subjected to audiological investigations and diagnosed to be a case of right-sided serous otitis media. What will be the priority in further management of this patient?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • This is a suspected case of Nasopharyngeal carcinoma(NPC).
  • The unilateral serous otitis media in an adult patient should always raise the suspicion of nasopharyngeal carcinoma.
  • Hence, Nasopharyngoscopy should be done, and a biopsy of any suspicious area should be taken. Myringotomy and grommet insertion will be done at a later date when NPC is ruled out.

questions.text: A 10-year-old child has fever, pain in the ear, and Otoscopy shows the tympanic membrane to be red & bulging. The treatment of choice is:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • This is a case of Acute Suppurative Otitis Media(ASOM) with a bulging eardrum. It is an impending perforation; hence, Myringotomy will be needed in the posterior inferior quadrant.
  • A grommet is only used in glue ear or Eustachian tube dysfunction.
  • It is an acute inflammation of the middle ear by pyogenic organisms. Here, middle ear implies middle ear cleft, eustachian tube, middle ear, attic, aditus, antrum and mastoid air cells.
  • It is more common, especially in infants and children of lower socioeconomic groups. Typically, the disease follows viral infection of the upper respiratory tract, but soon the pyogenic organisms invade the middle ear.
  • Antibiotics are first-line therapy. Clinical guidelines recommend antibiotic treatment for AOM in children with fever and moderate to severe symptoms, even if unilateral. First-line: highâ€‘dose amoxicillin unless contraindicated.
  • Myringotomy is indicated for relief of pressure and pain in cases of significant bulging or when intratympanic pressure is high and symptoms are severe. Myringotomy (needle aspiration of fluid) provides rapid pain relief and enhances antibiotic effectiveness.
  • Tympanostomy tubes (grommets) are premature in routine AOM.
    Grommet insertion is reserved for recurrent AOM or persistent effusion over months, not typically during a first or isolated acute episode.
  • More aggressive surgery (e.g., mastoidectomy) is unnecessary without complications like mastoiditis.

questions.text:
A 7-year-old girl presents with 2 days of worsening right ear pain and drainage. Her parents report redness and swelling behind the ear, with the pinna now protruding upward and outward. She was diagnosed with acute otitis media 5 days ago and started on amoxicillin, but symptoms worsened after initial improvement.

The most likely diagnosis is?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The mastoid surface is found to be smooth, red and shiny. This is called the Ironing of the mastoid surface. It is the first sign of Mastoiditis.

Explanation of relevant topic:

Mastoiditis :

It is an infection of the mastoid air cells. It is a complication of ASOM and CSOM.

Chief complaint:

  • Pain behind the pinna,
  • Profuse ear discharge

On examination-

  • The mastoid surface is found to be smooth, red and shiny. This is called the Ironing of the mastoid surface. It is the first sign of Mastoiditis.
  • Mastoid Tenderness is positive.
  • Reservoir sign on cleaning, the pus fills immediately again. This is because pus is continuously flowing from the mastoid to the middle ear, which is called Pulsatile Otorrhea.
  • The lighthouse sign is seen due to this pulsatile otorrhoea.

Investigation :

  • X-ray mastoid right and left lateral oblique view. It is called Schuller's view.
  • This is the most commonly used X-ray view for mastoids in ENT.

This X-ray shows two findings:

  • Clouding of air cells.
  • Coalescence of air cells.

Treatment :

  • Intravenous antibiotics for 48 hrs, if no recovery, then surgery.
  • Surgery is Cortical Mastoidectomy, also known as the Schwartz operation. The first cell to be located during mastoid surgery is the Antrum. The location of the Mastoid antrum is indicated by McEwen's triangle or the Suprameatal triangle.

Explanation of other options:

Otitis externa (Option A) primarily affects the ear canal skin (pain when touching the tragus) and doesn't cause postauricular swelling or pinna displacement.

Otitis media with effusion (Option B) may cause fluid behind the tympanic membrane but not pain, fever, or swelling behind the ear.

Lateral sinus thrombosis (Option D) is intracranial and presents with symptoms like headache, neck pain, cranial nerve palsies, or signs of increased intracranial pressure, not localised swelling or pinna protrusion.

questions.text: CT scan of a patient suffering from atticotympanic CSOM shows an abscess at the petrous apex. Which of the following is not a likely symptom in this case?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The above is a case of petrositis, as there is an abscess at the petrous apex and which is the most common complication of the atticotympanic CSOM.
  • The above three form the triad of Petrositis, except for that of Sensorineural hearing loss and hence it is not a likely symptom.

Spread of infection from the middle ear to the petrous bone is called Petrositis or Gradinego syndrome. This is a triad of:

  • Ear discharge
  • Deep-seated ear or Retro-orbital pain(CN V involvement)
  • Diplopia(CN VI involvement - Lateral rectus palsy)

Management:

  • First-line: Culture-directed IV antibiotics; many cases respond without needing surgery.
    Common regimens: ceftriaxone, vancomycin, metronidazole; antifungals if needed.
  • Surgical drainage (petrous apicectomy) is reserved for persistent or complicated cases, using approaches like transcanal intralabyrinthine or hypotympanic routes to drain the petrous apex while preserving hearing.
  • Cranial nerve palsies (especially VI) often resolve rapidly post-drainage

Key takeaways:

  • G-Gradinego syndrome(Comprises the clinical signs of petrositis).
  • E-Ear discharge
  • R-Retro Orbital pain due to 5th nerve
  • D-Diplopia due to 6th nerve.

questions.text: The image given below is a zoomed-in microscopic view of the floor of the mastoid cavity per-operatively while doing ear surgery. What is the most appropriate description of the surgical procedure being shown in the given image?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • This is the posterior tympanotomy window, which has been created at the facial recess. It is a surgical step in the transmastoid surgical approach of cochlear implantation.
  • This procedure involves drilling a tunnel through the mastoid into the middle ear by opening the facial recess-the space bounded by the facial nerve medially, chorda tympani laterally, and the incus buttress superiorly-after completing a cortical mastoidectomy.
  • The visual field shows the characteristic grey, porous bone of the facial recess area being drilled to gain access to structures like the round window niche-hallmarks of the posterior tympanotomy approach.

questions.text: A 6-year-old male child presented to the ENT emergency with left ear profuse ear discharge for the last 3 days, with lateral and forward displacement of the pinna. X-ray mastoid ( Schuller's view) revealed closure of air cells and destruction of cortical septations. What is the most probable Diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • A 6-year-old with profuse ear discharge, fever, and lateral/forward pinna displacement strongly suggests mastoid involvement with subperiosteal abscess formation.
  • Acute coalescent mastoiditis is defined by the acute form of destruction of the thin bony septae between mastoid air cells. It may be followed by the formation of abscess cavities and the dissipation of pus into adjacent areas.
  • Schüller's view X-ray showing opacification (clouding) of mastoid air cells along with the destruction of cortical septations indicates coalescence, where multiple air cells fuse due to pus accumulation and bony erosion.
  • These radiographic and clinical findings align with acute coalescent mastoiditis, a complication of acute otitis media that demands urgent attention.n

Explanation of other options:

Petrositis(Option A): Involves the petrous apex with symptoms like Gradenigo's triad (ear discharge, facial pain, abducens palsy), not just pinna displacement or localised mastoid changes.

Acute Necrotising Otitis Media(Option C): This term is misleading-"necrotising otitis externa" is seen in elderly diabetics, not ENT emergencies in kids with mastoid bone erosion.

Attic CSOM(Option D): A chronic condition involving cholesteatoma, more than acute presentation; wouldn't present with acute swelling or displaced pinna in a previously well child.

questions.text: A patient of 38 years of age has presented with painful fluctuant swelling in the left-sided lateral neck swelling in the middle part of the neck muscles in that area. The patient also mentions chronic ear discharge on the left side, with a recent history of an increase in the discharge of the ear, with pain in the mastoid region. What is the name of this swelling?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The Bezold abscess can occur following acute coalescent mastoiditis, a complication of middle ear infection, when the pus breaks through the thin medial side of the tip of the mastoid, presenting as a swelling in the upper part of the neck.

The Bezold's abscess may;

  • Lie deep to the sternocleidomastoid, pushing the muscle outwards,
  • Follow the posterior belly of the digastric and present as a swelling between the tip of the mastoid and the angle of the jaw,
  • Be present in the upper part of the posterior triangle,
  • Reach the parapharyngeal space or
  • Track down along the carotid vessels

Clinical features.:

  • Onset is sudden, and there is pain, fever, a tender swelling in the neck and torticollis.
  • Patient gives history of purulent otorrhoea.

A Bezold abscess should be differentiated from:

  • acute upper jugular abscess
  • abscess or a mass in the lower part of the parotid
  • An infected branchial cyst.
  • parapharyngeal
  • jugular vein

A computed tomography (CT) scan of the mastoid and swelling of the neck may establish the diagnosis.

Treatment:

  • Cortical mastoidectomy for coalescent mastoiditis with careful exploration of the tip for a fistulous opening into the soft tissues of the neck.
  • Drainage of the neck abscess through a separate incision and putting a drain in the dependent part.
  • Administration of intravenous antibiotics guided by the culture and sensitivity report of

Explanation of other options:

Citelli's abscess(Option A): spreads along the digastric muscle triangle, presenting differently.
Luc's abscess(Option C) is subperiosteal over the mastoid, not deep neck.
Pott's puffy tumour Option C): involves frontal bone osteomyelitis with forehead swelling.
